I can see how the everyday horror fan would not like this. But, I completely loved this movie. I like horror, and I also like really good movies. This is an excellent movie that is a horrifying story. This movie does not give you any cheap jumps, is not gory, and is very slow paced. It also doesn't give you anything to laugh at, as a lot of horror movies do with their impossible and unbelievable situations. This in itself is unnerving. And I found it also very difficult to identify with the characters - an extremely puritanical family of 7 - leaving one just an observer of this strange foreign world and getting pulled into it, almost without realizing. If you go into it with expectations, you'll find yourself impatient, looking for cheap thrills, and will end up disappointed - if you go with no expectations, and just sit and watch, you'll find yourself with your eyes and mouth wide open as the film slowly pulls you in and itself apart.

As other reviewers have said, "The Witch" is not a movie that scares you with the tired old tricks, or tries to make you jump out of your seat. It did chill me to the bone, however. The setting, the dialogue, the score, a goat named Black Phillip, all worked well together to creep me the hell out. I was a bit disappointed by the ending, or maybe just confused by the choice to end it in that manner. I'd still recommend this movie to anyone looking for an entertaining, different, kind of movie. Great to see some originality these days. Also, Black Phillip, may be the best name of any character (human or animal) ever.

THE WITCH disgorges a deferential awe to the mysticism and regards our human folly with a cold glare "In the thick of its blame-throwing, hallucination-effecting, sin-confessing chaos, all hell breaks loose with predictable outcomes, sinners must pay for their sins, whether it is pride or wrath, and Thomasin, ever elfin and dainty as a wide-eyed hare, eventually confirms our trepidation when she signs a book with the devil and eventually relishes in a witches' sabbath. Anya Taylor-Joy is a revelation who abandons herself to the rawest emotional states, while the close-knit cast is overall impressive, Ralph Ineson is alternatively sympathetic and antipathetic (when the Electra complex gives way to entrenched oscillation) as the beleaguered breadwinner, a gaunt-looking Kate Dickie stands out from the crowd as a tremendous force of grief, ire and desolation, by the same token, child actor Harvey Scrimshaw might touch on overacting in his final emotive outpouring of demonic possession." read my full review on my blog: cinema omnivore

Review_Title: Not only the worst horror film I've ever seen but probably the worst film I've ever seen.
Review_Text: Please. Please. If you want to save your money and two hours of your life, don't see this film... I'm a horror enthusiast and this was not horror at all. The first 10 minutes you feel like it has potential and than absolutely nothing happens from then on. The film needs sub titles because you can literally probably understand about 15%-20% of what they are saying. I have no idea who would rate this film as being good. If you're a critic and thought this was a good film you should probably reconsider your profession. Atrocious film that should of been made exclusively for Netflix. Don't waste your money or time on this film you'll regret it!

For those who are horror fans know how to truly appreciate a movie for what it's worth,this is everything you have dreamed of. It really gets under you skin and resonates in you mind long after the movie is over. There is so much meaning to it. Each character is unique and the third act is fantastic. Its a slow burning movie but that really isn't a problem at all. It's fantastically atmospheric and meaningful. My only fear is that the general public won't see the brilliance of this film because unfortunately were stuck in an age where people want a quick thrill with hardly any substance at all. This is not that film. Its so much more. Its shame that it's been wasted on the general public of today.

Review_Title: Actors did a great job in a mediocre movie. Horror? Not.
Review_Text: I had seen this movie compared to "The Shining" in reviews. Maybe because they both had credits, were in color and were put on film, but that is the only thing they have in common. The Shining is a masterpiece of horror and suspense. This is just a piece of..well, I digress. Other than the three "cheap scares", using overblown music and jump out tactics, and the BAD rubber prosthetic makeup, there was no horror. There was little suspense. There was a cheesy plot. There were undefined conflicts. This was a historically accurate (Except for the machine woven knit cap) piece that tried to be something it wasn't. It missed across the board. And BORED is what I was. I do give high marks to the actors, that handled the archaic language nuances and seemed to be in character, but a mediocre script, and a lack of intensity/direction sunk this flick. My wife, a big horror /paranormal movie fan, was disappointed as well. I should have known something was up when links to the "preview/trailer" landed on the Director explaining how he tried to be authentic to the time period. The three mildly scary parts were the entire movie in a nutshell, so there was no need to spend $20 to see it. Wait for it on Netfix and go see "Deadpool" again.
Amazingly terrifying.Spoilers ahead.

Another great horror film from director Robert Eggers. The first half of the film may be slow, but for me it is gripping, the setting, soundtrack and even the costumes seemed creepy. Anya Taylor-Joy really is a great actress, who goes well hand in hand with the director. I loved several scenes that I personally found very scary and refreshing for horror movies, and that are accompanied with excellent performances and dialogues that can leave the viewer tense.

There are multiple interpretations that have been offered on this opaque masterpiece, but the one I like most is that the piece is an example of a group hysteria that goes really badly wrong, or at least it's too simple to just blame the nymph-like beauty at the heart of the film for being 'a witch all along'. She actually comes across as the most saintly character up until the denouement. In the meticulously crafted dialogue of first-generation American pilgrims one becomes immersed in the wierd mindscape of 17th century Puritans, where there's an unflinching belief in the supernatural - be it heavenly or hellish... Somehow the horror seemed just so much more genuine here than amidst the usual comic stumbling fiends that make up the stock of the tired genre.. Anyway I loved it from start to finish, and felt such a transgressive kick, a liberated feeling becoming involved in a vicarious way with the goings on. One witnesses in subtle symbolism and audacious moments a bit of everything from murder to incest, suppressed greed & vanity, obsession in bucketloads, pubertal lust, love mingled with hate, hopes for salvation meeting fire & brimstone, to name a few. And it was all so much more pointed and realistic in the austere, sprititalised and just plain paranoid setting that the director so painstakingly creates. This is far too clever and too serious to be pidgeon-holed as 'horror'. It's more of a psychological thriller with buckets of blood and bible-talk. And the suggestion online that the whole family were all hallucinating on the ergot from rotten corn is way too delicious an idea to dismiss outright.

It had potential. whether it was a case of lack of budget for the film production or just bad directing; the story was good however was lacking any a lot of areas. the scenery chosen was fantastic and acting was good also. the combination of the actors/actress working together was also a good selection. The voice of the father was prime for the film that gave an extra feel for the movie. His voice alone warranted one of my three stars for the film. That's pretty much where the niceties stop. It did not draw the audience in, at least not this viewer. i long for a good suspenseful armchair gripping scary movie which do not come all too often. after completing the movie, well i expected more.

Well, this is something! It is - as it is labeled - a horror film but also a mystery film. I would add that this is kinda a fairy tale. Are witches in fairy tales?Or only the good princesses and nice things?! Anyway, the film is quite good. I really liked the performances of all characters in the movie. Really convincing and utterly believable! The oldest boy was phenomenal! The oldest girl too, but really, every role was perfectly acted! I really had a feeling I was in the 15th or 16th century. The mood and the tone of the film totally transports you to those dark ages of new puritan America and those religious fanatics... We have the devil in the movie, but I must say that the figure of father was reminiscent of Jesus ( on purpose or not - and maybe it is only my thought - did not read other reviews yet). The film is disturbing at times. The witch is ... well, I am not sure if there is only one witch or there are many in the film ( not counting the last scene) who were after the family. The sounds ( I would not really call it music) was totally dramatic! It fits the mood / color of the film. The last witch dance and those sounds were ... chilly!!! All in all, this is really a great film. Fairy tale horror I would say. Definitely would recommend to anyone!

As with most modern horror films, the premise of "The Witch" is tired, the visuals bleak for "effect," and the writing is terrible. What irked me most was that it began with promise and tapered off into a wandering, laughable tale that rang of cautionary tales told to young children to scare them into behaving, which, according to the disclaimer in the credits, is where the source material was derived. Clearly, however, there is a market for this drivel, as evidenced by the glowing critical reviews here. Another reviewer stated that "'The Witch' lives...as a horror movie for cinephiles, not for audiences who love the thrill of a good scare." As a cinephile, I can state with certainty that a true cinephile would do well to steer clear of "The Witch" and choose to watch "Dumb and Dumber" to cleanse their mental palate and to again appreciate clarity of purpose in film.

Review_Title: Original and Well Executed Horror Film
Review_Text: I love horror films. Despite the many I've seen, this is the first of any film I've been compelled to comment upon. Many currently titles seem to focus on a couple of good scenes which you see most of in the trailer. The rest is mostly filler to help the story along which may not receive as much attention. I believe "The Witch" to be a rare exceptions. The story, storytelling, acting, and directing alone would have been enough to make a good movie, but the combination of all parts made it incredible. I cannot remember any dull moments in this film. The story, drama, and horror steadily crescendos until the last second. I must admit that the trailer didn't impress me. There are parts of the film which could have been added to make a better trailer, but it would have given away too much (as is the case so often). Overall, I don't think you'll find another recent horror film which executes everything close to the degree of "The Witch." Well done! Cannot wait for the next film from Robert Eggers!

Review_Title: Psychological Horror Meets Family Period Piece.
Review_Text: The Witch has been receiving a lot of buzz recently from horror fans and Sundance Film Festival attendees. Writer/Director Roboert Eggers even won the Best Director award at the festival. So does it live up to what people are saying? Well yes, but you have to know what you're getting in to. Knowing that this is a smaller indie film from Sundance and that it isn't going to be your run of the mill, make-a- quick- buck horror movie there is a lot of great stuff here. This film combines two things that I am not the biggest fan, period pieces and horror, and, surprisingly, make them work. in his first film, Eggers does a fantastic job and building and sustaining tension. The atmosphere of the film never lets up making for suspense that really gets under the skin in moments where it really counts. Furthermore, the actors were just as equally great as the direction, at first, the older dialect was hard to follow and didn't feel very natural. But after about ten minutes, the language flows better and every thing becomes very believable. Going on with the believability, everything in the landscape and surroundings felt as thought it fit the time period. The film just pulls you into the time period where you fell the struggles as the family does. There was a point where I had to look around the theater to make sure that I was indeed not in Old England. The one thing that might be off-putting to some will be that the story isn't exactly about a witch versus a family. The story focuses much more on the family aspect as we see every family member deal with grief in their own ways as they sink deeper and deeper a psychological trance. There aren't as many straight up "scares" as one might hope, but there no doubt be times that make you jump and make you gut wrench. The family struggle is the fuel that drives the story forward and it makes for some great dramatic acting from adult and child actors alike. As for problems, there are a few, but none to detract from the tension and drama that the film builds. The film is very gray and bleak, and at some points, it can be a little overwhelming at times, where you wish the color palette would liven up. To continue, there was a point where I thought the mother character was a little one- note, but I just assumed that it was her way of dealing with grief since she is obviously the one that gets hits the hardest in family problems. The ending can be polarizing to some, I wish there was a even a little more ambiguity, but the way Eggers decided to end is sufficient enough. Lastly, a note must be made about the music and cinematography, both add to the film wonderfully and enthrall the viewer into whatever Eggers wants them to see. Overall, The Witch is a very good horror film, certainly a brilliant start for Robert Eggers and easily a mark or two above the average horror film that is released nowadays. The closest thing I can compare this film to would be The Shining. So, just know what kind of film you are getting in to and you won't leave disappointed. "Wouldst thou like to live deliciously?"

Review_Title: The best horror movie in the last 20 years.
Review_Text: A very smart slow paced horror film. The historical setting was very well done. This is a film you can watch a few times and in each viewing find something new and interesting. The Blu Ray is clean and clear, the film looks very good for a low budget horror. It was shot digitally and has a nice smooth look. The camera work is very assured and the film is well edited and flows naturally. It also features real animals thankfully not CGI ones, practical effects I would say, great lighting when it's needed. In fact it looks as though there's a lot of natural lighting, both in the outdoors, the moonlight, or candle lit interiors which manage to bring a little colour and warmth to some scenes. The cast was very small but all did very well with what they were given. The film doesn't make any of the characters too likeable actually but that helps with some of the realism. The title I would say is a bit misleading, the film has very little to do with the witch, she's in it for about 35 seconds all in all. The script is really good, you have a small cast so get to spend lots of time with them and to know and understand their dynamic as a group. Things which happen later on are nicely foreshadowed earlier such as the oldest daughter cruelly joking about going out at night and dancing naked with the devil which in the end she basically does. Equally the earlier scenes involving the goat hint at the violence to come. The low light and night shots are very well handled, the picture never becomes noisy. Equally there's no awful day for night attempt either, things actually look like they do at night, with just a bit of moonlight for lighting. The story appears to be set in the 17th or early 18th century and the script nicely utilises some old English, the props, costumes, casting all perfectly sell the period, we don't get some annoying modern comedian in one of the roles or a racially diverse cast playing the same family or anything terrible like that. Old the actors do really well in this film with what they are given, the actress playing the mother is probably the best actually, and also the most unlikeable character too. The film focuses heavily on religion, less so on the love and hope aspect of Christianity but in this case on the sins and corruption of mankind. The devil when he does appear wears black, is tall, wears a black hat and appears to have a black moustache. He speaks in a seductive yet strong whisper, he's able to tempt and seduce. It's a very creepy portrayal. The film somehow manages to make everyday animals scary, hares, birds and goats all seem threatening and sinister. The landscape is largely colourless and the family find themselves struck down by grief, hunger, sleep deprivation, this all causes them to start to turn on each other. This family conflict is really more interesting than the witch in the end, though there is some man v nature conflict in there too. The family live a largely humourless, puritanical life, it's little wonder the children are so troubled. The eldest boy is starting to become interested in his elder sisters body. The film avoids any glamour at all, the two parents look especially thin, lean, grubby and weather beaten. This is a film without loud jump scares, it's a million miles from the over the top hysterical loud horror movies like the Conjuring, Insidious or Paranormal Activity. Much more interestingly there's a thread of paranoia running through it, just like many great horror films like Rosemary's baby or the Shining. Some of the religious are also worth diving into. Man's nature is described as corrupt, wicked, selfish and destructive, it's hard to argue with any of that. However the eldest son cannot help but wonder what sins his new born baby brother could have committed? How could he be born a sinner? The poster mirrors the scene we get at the end of the film of the eldest daughter stepping out naked into the woods, seduced by the devil. The presence of the witch in the film is sinister, many misdeeds are attributed to her but it's more the psychological horror and tension which make this film so good.
I love a well made movie, but this one is just stifling boring. Not much else to say.

Review_Title: The evil that lives within us all
Review_Text: The Witch is a movie about a small family that lives in 17th century New England. They're far removed from their nearest community, all alone on their farm. Hard-working, religious and fervent in their world views. So what would happen if they started fearing that the Devil himself had infected one of their own? The film is the feature directional debut of Robert Eggers, who's worked in theater before this one, mainly as a production designer. And that definitely shows. The attention to detail in this film is astonishing. Everything from the location to the set designs to the costumes is about as period accurate as possible. Even the dialogue and the accents utilized by the actors is straight from 1630s Plymouth Colony. The only way to make this more accurate would be to invent a time machine and actually film in the 1600s. As for the horror aspect of the story, it works very well. The film is in no hurry and doesn't rely on cheap jump scares to get you to sit on the edge of your seat. Rather it relies on atmosphere and good character building. Its characters are fearful, frail and flawed. And when the pressure is put on them, they turn on one another. If jump scares are being shanked with a knife, then this film would be the slow agony of a screw press. And when the violence inevitably comes, it's all the more horrifying because you've been waiting for it for so long. Easily one of the best horror films I've seen in years. Also one of the best period films I've seen in years. Heartily recommended.

Another review called this "a horror for cinephiles" and that struck me for some reason. It made me what to write this. Indeed, I suppose it is a movie for "cinephiles" - but I don't see that as praise and it made me really consider the term cinephile. I have seen thousands of movies. I'm part of a movie group that has been running for years and each week we rotate a movie pick and watch it. I have taken film classes in university and learned how to study film like any good "cinephile". I like to analyze movies like any good "cinephile". I can admire strong direction, unique filmography, and appreciate difficult shots like say a room has a lot of mirrors and there's no visible crew and camera - like any good "cinephile". Where apparently myself and other "cinephiles" differ is that a true "cinephile" must always praise boring period piece movies. I don't know what it is exactly. Unlike other "cinephiles" I hold the opinion that the absolute worst thing a movie can be is boring. I have seen Battleship Potemkin with a live orchestra playing, and I've also gone to live screenings of Rocky Horror Picture Show. I know what one the "cinephile" will say was an enriching cultural experience - but what one do you think was more fun? Why must that been the only metric films are judged on? Why can't a movie being a good time be an admirable quality? Like every good film student of yore I had to watch my share of the classics and I always felt crazy. La Dolce Vita? I wanted to fall asleep. Jean Luc Godard? I saw it as meandering pretentious art pieces. On the other hand while Neil Breen has made some of the most objectively terrible movies of the last decade I can't deny turning on one of his movies with some friends and just laughing ourselves sick is a night I'm going to remember more than analyzing Yasujiro Ozu's "The Flavor of Green Tea over Rice" and trying to reflect on it's representation of pre-war Japanese family structure. So, as it comes to the VVitch - this is most certainly a movie for the critics. A movie for the staunches of cinephiles. A movie for those who hate fun. A movie for those who hate horror. A movie for those who feel authentic period costumes and hard to listen to old timey English are what film is *supposed* to be. The movie is well made, well shot, the language is (as far as I know) authentic and I'm sure there's lots of allegory and imagery you're supposed to love to analyze. Unfortunately it commits what is, to me, the gravest of movie sins. One which all cultural reflection, meaning, symbolism, imagery and Oscar bait period piece themes can't make up for - the only "horror" in this movie is in that it's horrifically boring.

To put it simply, Robert Eggers delivers a terrorizing horror in the form of 'The Witch'. Do not go into this film expecting cheesy jump scares and scary apparitions. This one does not do that. Instead, 'The Witch' delivers a slow terror, unnerving, and mentally exhausting horror. The constant questioning of what is happening leaves the audience uneasy and when this film finally starts to pick up, it consistently bludgeons the audience with eerie terror. Some dislikes I did have, however, were that the old English is sometimes hard to follow and it can be found as being slow at some parts but it is all part of the style that Eggers is delivering his haunting moments. This is another Indie win for the creative horror category. I would place it among the ranks of last years creative beast that was 'It Follows'. Check this film out and try to keep your sanity.

The Witch, director Robert Eggers' debut film, is an atmospherically terrifying tale of manipulation and paranoia. 2016 was a pretty solid year for horror films, with major releases like Don't Breathe and 10 Cloverfield Lane faring well with audiences and critics. While many releases were sequels, prequels, or lazy reboots, there were several that ended up as genuinely scary films. The Witch, an indie gem distributed by A24 (Ex Machina, Swiss Army Man), is one of these, and many people simply haven't heard of it. I'm not going to hide how much I like this movie. It fascinates me. I'm generally not much of a horror fan, but at the end of the day, a good movie is just a good movie. The story takes place in 16th-century New England and follows a Puritan family of seven who have recently been banished from a plantation settlement. Distressed, they set out blindly into the wild, in hopes of building a new home for themselves. When a witch from the nearby forest abducts their youngest, the mother of the family completely snaps, and the rest must try to survive in the untamed wilderness as their relationships and minds deteriorate further. As they grow more paranoid and even accuse the oldest daughter of witchcraft, they threaten to destroy themselves. The pacing of this film has remained its most contentious quality among audiences since its release. The slow and deliberate pacing starkly contrasts the exciting scare-fests that more casual horror fans expect today. Instead, this movie is oppressively tense, refusing to break the mood that it builds at almost any point. What the pacing and atmosphere of this film are able to create is utterly horrifying. The witch herself is introduced to us in just about the most repulsive way possible, and from that point onward, the film essentially builds as an hour-and-a-half nightmare. Without the relief provided by unearned jump scares, the tension from these scenes builds mercilessly and doesn't let up. I also have to be sure to mention the acting in this film. Each member of the family, which serves as most of the cast of the movie, is thoroughly believable, from the parents to the young twins. While children in movies are with rare exceptions painfully hard to watch, both the child and adult actors in The Witch give convincing performances. This is a film featuring many relative unknowns who can remind us that a film doesn't have to be helmed by A-list stars to be effective. In particular, lead actress Anya Taylor-Joy delivered a well-rounded and convincingly emotional performance; I'm excited to see where her career takes her over the next several years. The characters' mutual descent into madness is reminiscent of Stanley Kubrick's 1980 masterpiece The Shining. Visually, they are both exquisitely constructed, though instead of the bright symmetry of the older film, The Witch presents itself visually in a sharp grayness of frank poverty, uncomfortable character closeups, and shrieking nature shots. Honestly, you'll end up afraid of just about everyone and everything in the movie from the paranoia that the visuals help produce and the chilling score of period instruments and melismatic chanting help to fully bring out. There's a terribly vulnerable nakedness to the characters' condition in their small homestead. Protected from the wilderness by a shabby split rail fence, the members of this family appear so cold and fragile. While the titular witch is the villain behind what happens to and between this family, the land around them is so oppressively ambivalent that it become a villain all its own. The film is a surprisingly spiritual film. Christian iconography is common in western horror films, but The Witch is able to meaningfully incorporate otherwise cliché themes and imagery into its narrative. The characters are deeply religious, often praying and quoting scripture, though a good deal of drama and tension derives from how horribly they treat each other in the worst times. By rejecting the joy and forgiveness that is central to the Christian faith, this devout family allows for a very real and present evil to tear them apart. Each of these characters is fast to instruct the others to pray for forgiveness because they refuse to offer it to each other, and in the end, they all suffer horribly. Beyond its strengths as a horror film, The Witch is an undeniable accomplishment of period filmmaking. From the characters' way of life and view of the world to their immediately apparent costumes and speech, most elements of this film are placed and held believably within seventeenth century America. The dialog could have sounded contrived and artificial, and given the inexperience of many of the actors involved, I am impressed by how well it turned out. Director Robert Eggers heavily researched speech, farming, religious attitudes, and more from the time period portrayed in order to authentically transport us there; his efforts paid off. I particularly appreciate his transformation of dialog produced by twentieth century actors into everyday speech of seventeenth century English expats. To my knowledge, the accent that the characters use in the film is accurate to what the English language sounded like at that time. The words used are also largely accurate; Eggers went as far as to incorporate records of actual alleged possessions and bewitchings from around that period in time into scenes in the film. The ease with which these lines fit the rest of the film is a testament to his efforts. It's a shame that because of this movie's pacing and relatively understated scares I can't recommend it to many horror enthusiasts, but that hardly takes away from its artistic quality. The Witch is a testament to what can be accomplished in a film conceived and driven by a passionate and skilled mind. It is proof that there is more to the horror genre today whatever Blumhouse Productions is pumping out this month. Like the best horror films, it exists where fear and helplessness meet and holds you there with it until the screen has gone black.

Review_Title: Not scary, but worth seeing anyway
Review_Text: Horror is inherently a very subjective genre. It is about as subjective as comedy, perhaps even more so. Both comedy and horror are ruled by emotions that vary widely from person to person. For example, most critics hate Adam Sandler comedies (with a few exceptions) but audiences still receive them. Why? Because they find it funny. The same can be said for horror. Paranormal Activity has gone stale for most people, but there are still a lot of people that watch it. Why? Because they think it's scary. There are going to be people that like the new Ghostbusters movie, and people that are going to like the new 'The Ring' reboot that is coming out this year (seriously). The Witch, like 'It Follows' and 'The Babadook' before it, follows a trend of critically acclaimed, slow paced psychological horror movies that perhaps unintentionally market themselves as epic monster pieces that are full of scares. The Witch isn't full of scares. The concepts behind it are scary, but you won't jump in your seat. I didn't at least. The Witch is a mellow piece that builds tension over time. The cinematography is beautiful, the writing is moody and matches the time period, the music is amazing (probably my favourite part) and the young leading actress Anya Taylor-Joy was incredible in her role as Thomasin. I liked it a lot, but it didn't scare me. I won't be having nightmares because of this film, and that is slightly disappointing. If you're able to appreciate this film for its story, watch it, but if you're looking for a movie to scare you out of your skin, this isn't it, unless you're afraid of Christian fundamentalism and/or naked old women.

Review_Title: Was expecting great horror but what a let down.
Review_Text: I was looking forward to this. At long last a great horror that will keep you on the edge pf your seat...or so I thought. Wrong. The good points: the first 30 minutes was good, the natural lighting was great, the look of the film was authentic and acting excellent. That said the main problem with this is the pace, slow and dull, and I mean SLLLLOOOWWW. Luckily I could fast forward the long boring dull bits otherwise in a cinema I'd have walked out. It's more a pretentious religious docu-drama with a touch of supernatural thrown in rather than a "horror". A classic? 10 out of 10? No way!! Would I watch it again? Nope.

Review_Title: This is how you make a horror film
Review_Text: What a film. I generally don't like horror movies because I get annoyed by the standard Hollywood formula. It's refreshing to see something that is disturbingly all kinds of wrong. The Witch is not a jump-out-of-your-seat-in-terror-brown-your-pants horror film but what makes this film especially unnerving is that it feels real and plausible. Indeed, this story is inspired by a series of historical accounts. The story begins with a family in the new frontier of the US in the 1630s getting banished from their township and their attempts to create a new life by the edge of a forest. Nothing else need be said. Just watch and squirm and be prepared to look away. There are some truly unsettling moments. I can tolerate all sorts of weird and freaky stuff with my movie watching habits, but the Witch had me rattled and I've not quite figured out why or how. The entire cast was amazing - the guy from the Office who plays Chris the sleazeball, that creepy Lysa Arryn from Game of Thrones, all four children, led by striking newcomer Anya Taylor-Joy who was impressive as Thomasin, the eldest sibling. The eerie soundtrack and the use of shadows in the cinematography were also very effective. The manner in which this was filmed places the viewers in the midst of the family's struggles making us helpless voyeurs and at times maybe complicit... I'll stop right here. This is exactly how horror films should be done. It is one of the best horror films I've seen in a loooooong time. Very promising feature debut by director Robert Eggers. Here's looking forward to see how he translates Nosferatu as his new project. Really impressive. Go see it.

Pretentious, affected, over-acted, poorly written. One for pseudo intellectuals who think that setting something in a historical context and scripting a film in mock medieval English elevates twaddle to art.

New England, 1630: a family, away from society, faces the forces of darkness, black magic and constant fear. A horror film that should be the standard for the genre, not "1 in 1000", as it turns out. The atmosphere created since the beginning leads the viewer to question the actions and motives of the characters, the narrative begins with doubts about their past, which forces the viewer to be alert to every detail, in order to try to understand what's going on in this weird family. The main factor is the psychological terror, based on religious fanaticism, typical of that time, and also on paranoia and tension accumulated between people who live inside a bubble, which in this case is not about comfort, but fear. The film takes various bits from various tales of supernatural folklore, and assembles a very interesting set.

Review_Title: A faboulous and terryfing story of how religion can become obsession.
Review_Text: The best horror of the last 15 years... Robert Eggers is the new Friedrich Murneau.
Modern Masterpiece!

Lets start with the positive. The atmosphere, the realistic village/home setting, the visuals and the audio are all absolutely outstanding. They really are, you can see the amount of effort the crew have gone to to make an authentic world for their film. The negative. The actual movie. God it's so boring. The basics of the story is fine and had the concepts of something interesting to explore (and does somewhat) but a lack of real drama and punch rob the movie of the factors that could have made this a great movie.
''Thou shall not understand without subtitles''
This movie sucked massive gorilla donkey d!ck

'The Witch' is a powerful, imaginative and hauntingly captivating folk horror film written and directed by Robert Eggers in his feature debut. The movie presents an engaging slow burn tale of estrangement, betrayal and exile which takes on many forms throughout the story and does a phenomenal job of building mood, atmosphere and tension as well as some well-crafted suspense and frightening set pieces resulting in a unique and enthralling viewing experience that will stay with you long after it's over. The Plot = Set in New England during the 1630's, A Puritan family finds themselves banished from their community over a religious dispute. They build a farm near a large, secluded forest, only to be preyed upon by an evil force in the woods. This is the kind of movie that reminds me of why I love the horror genre so much, a deeply thought-provoking and visually stunning masterpiece that works on just about every level with incredible performances, authentic set pieces and the harsh reality of the time period really pulls you in and while the movie doesn't quite play out as a traditional mainstream horror flick, it does an excellent job of building atmospheric tension and plenty of unnerving dread and presents a story filled with drama, paranoia, melancholy and fear. The direction by Robert Eggers is simply outstanding as his style fully immerses you into the period setting with powerful storytelling and subtle techniques to present an original viewing experience and one the very best horror movies to come out from the 2010's. The performances here are extraordinary with Anya Taylor Joy who steals the show as Thomasin the eldest and rebellious daughter with her captivating screen presence and excellent performance. Ralph Ineson and Kate Dickie each delivers incredible and formidable performances as the parents as their heartbreaking descent into helplessness is harrowing to watch. Harvey Scrimshaw gives a remarkable performance as the eldest son Caleb. Overall 'The Witch' is a remarkable, stylish and harrowing horror movie viewing experience that may not suit everybody's taste, but for fans of true slow-burn masterpieces then this is for you.

Seeing that this movie takes into account for a few stories of witches is good. I love this time period of early American colonial period. The imagery of the black goat and the young children love for role play as witches makes you wonder if they had communication with the devil. I loved Anya and Ralph's characters ( and Ralph's voice). Thomasin is being accused as being the witch, which we find who is later. The Witch overall is a great movie.
Not the usual horror
Pointless and not very successful exercise in mood

Give the movie a chance! There are so much layers of folklore in there it will amaze you the more you find out, and we're not even speaking about the movie. The camerawork is as good as perfect, the tones and sounds are just as they need to be! The background is correct with the time and fits perfect with the story. The story is for you to find out yourself! Enjoy.
Horrible movie!!
I don't like horror movies but through the Around The Web references list as the flawless movies I came across it and me and my wife we enjoyed it so much.

Review_Title: A Haunting Tapestry of Imagery and Psychological Intensity in Horror Cinema
Review_Text: The Witch stands as an exceptional piece in the realm of horror cinema, captivating audiences with its intense atmosphere and powerful imagery. Each shot in the film is meticulously crafted, speaking volumes without the need for words. The depiction of witchcraft is both beautiful and frightening, striking a perfect balance that intrigues and unnerves in equal measure. The soundtrack complements the visuals flawlessly, enhancing the eerie and unsettling ambiance of the film. This combination of striking imagery and haunting audio creates an atmosphere that is both mesmerizing and disconcerting, drawing the viewer deeper into the film's dark world. The performances are outstanding, with each actor delivering a strong and compelling portrayal of their character. Their performances add depth to the already rich narrative, making the film's tense and foreboding atmosphere even more palpable. What sets "The Witch" apart is its storytelling approach, which heavily relies on the interpretation of the viewer. The narrative is crafted in a way that encourages personal reflection and analysis, leaving much to the imagination and interpretation of the audience. While the film may not be conventionally scary, it has an undeniable psychological heaviness. Certain scenes are particularly impactful, resonating with a profound intensity that can be unsettling, especially for those in a low mood. In conclusion, The Witch is a remarkable horror film characterized by its powerful imagery, eerie soundtrack, and exceptional tension. It hits hard, leaving a lasting impact and opening doors for deep reflection and interpretation. It's a must-watch for anyone seeking a thoughtful and artistically crafted horror experience.

Review_Title: Took several viewings but I now find it quite good
Review_Text: At first viewing I was quite low on this one and just couldn't get into it, perhaps that was somewhat to do with the hype the movie had around it and the way it was marketed. Make no mistake that the vvitch is NOT some goretastic bloodbath by any stretch of the imagination. Instead this movie relies heavily on its atmosphere and the strength of the performances and cinematography to incite fear into the audience. As many strong horror films have done before this one, its what you don't see that frightens you and what you do see only aids to push your imagination further into the descent of despair that the characters of this film are slowly sliding into. I've watched it 3 times now and each time its far better than the previous viewing and the atmosphere, environment, the dialect spoken, the writing, and most of all the choices made while shooting the film (the very bleak almost gray cloudy washed out tone of the movie that seems to get more encroaching and restricting as the film develops) all make it more interesting than the previous viewing.
Horrible story. They yell and scream the entire movie. There is no plot. Acting is subpar. Save the time and go wash your cat instead. It will be more enjoyable!
Atmospheric, authentic and utterly terrifying

Review_Title: One of the films where the trailer is rather better
Review_Text: I'm not going to say much about this film beyond that the trailer misrepresented it. We were expecting a scary movie. It isn't. At all. For that dishonesty, it really deserves one out of ten. But, as a period piece and a reasonably well done depiction of an isolated family falling victim to their silly superstitions, it is a better prospect altogether. I don't understand why people didn't understand the dialogue - unless they aren't native English speakers. It was simple stuff, a tad King James Bible-ish, and no-doubt fairly authentic for the period in which the film is set. Oh, before I forget. Letting the screen go blank, for several seconds, every few minutes is a trick which went out of fashion in the 1920s. It doesn't achieve anything nowadays. I read a comment which said that people who mark this film down obviously don't know anything about the horror genre. I suggest, instead, that the people who know nothing of the horror genre are those who made the film. Perhaps three from ten is overly generous.
This movie is too much for some people

You dont need jumpscares, heavy background score, creepy creatures to produce a horror movie to terrify you.. Robert Eggers proves that in his directorial debut. He created this traditional horror which was inspired from the folklores and myths. The movie is so intense and makes you walk through the fears till the end of the movie. The sets, ambience, natural lighting, camerawork, the tense and mellow background score will keeps you in the world of fear. The movie was set in 1600s where a religious family of seven tested by the evil forces. Anya Taylor Joy on her debut delivers a brilliant performance along with Ralph Ineson. Jarin Balschke's camerawork is commendable and Mark Korven's music added more essence to the movie. Worth a Watch.. 8 on 10.

Review_Title: Takes a particular type of horror movie to scare me but...
Review_Text: This one The Witch at times left me feeling quite uneasy. Don't know if it was the slow pace at which the story line developed or the gradual disintegration of the family unit by way of such extreme malevolence forces, a force that so determinedly took hold of a family. The helplessness of viewer who could clearly see and realize that there was going to be no escape that there was going to be no sudden reprieve for the family only added to the utter level of foreboding that carried right through the movie I thought it was great but seriously disturbing the poor souls obviously having means of defense against
Lost two precious hours of my life watching this thing.
This movie is very scary in a psychological aspect and is horrific
A 6.8? Really?

Review_Title: A fantastic introduction to a brilliant Director!
Review_Text: The Witch is an original story set in the early 1600s and surrounds a New England Prutian family that is forcefully excommunicated. While on the break of starting a new chapter, they will encounter evils beyond their wildest dreams and will have their faith withstand the ultimate test. Not only is the film written by and the directorial debut of Robert Eggars. We are formally introduced to the wonderful Anya Taylor Joy, who gives us a career breaking performance as our lead. The cast is relatively small and most of the film stands on their shoulders. Ralph Ineson and Kate Dickie play the parents and absolutely deliver. The film's gray nature sets the tone as a unique timepiece and that hooked me instantly. The costumes are time accurate, their accents fit perfectly, every frame is shot with extreme precision and just gives off a dark, misty, evil presence. At the end of the day, this is a horror film, And in recent years more and more horror flicks tend to rely on a basic formula: jump scares and slashers. Frankly, I find that boring. What I love about horror and thrillers is their ability to build tension from almost nothing. Just by the pacing, or the music, or any other creative way really. It doesn't need to have gore, it isn't dependant on the regular phenomenon that you would normally see. I love Robert Eggers. His unique way of directing. His loyalty to accuracy. Each one of his films marks a milestone in this crazy world of storytelling and I honestly can't wait for more of him. The witch is a fantastic watch. Embrace it, soak it in, enjoy it. It's a hell of a ride and a wonderful introduction to the Horror, Thriller genre.

I quite enjoyed this movie. Yes, it's a horror film that I liked because the beginning and the buildup of the conflict were so engaging. I enjoyed the rising tension, but here's the issue: when the conflict reached its peak toward the end, I didn't feel the same excitement. It felt awkward and almost lazy, like I was expecting a more explosive ending or resolution. However, visually, with the scoring, and the actors' performances, everything was very well done. I really liked the depiction of the time period, and I got immersed in each character's role. The scoring was also spot on for me. I might be a bit biased, but I genuinely loved the setting and the actor, which is why I gave it a fairly high rating. So, I can only say that this movie was quite thrilling and enjoyable!

Along with 'You won't be alone' The Witch (or VVitch) is a truly brilliant take on a story about witches in the woods. The fact this is filmed with an olde English dialogue definitely lends this movie a sense of authenticity. Alongside acting of amazingly high standards. Each character portrayed with such power. Anya Taylor Joy breaks out quickly in this role as a downtrodden young woman living with a family of highly religious and abusive people. A young woman who wants to "Live deliciously". The story is strong and the tension is there all the way through the film as even seemingly innocent childhood games and nursery rhymes have deeper darker meanings than expected. This isn't an easy watch but it's a classy one and entertains for the entire running time. And there's a killer ending!

Very boring movie can't watch it more than twenty minutes it's slow dull not scary at all most irritating part was the night scenes it's so dark you can hardly see any thing on screen. Instead they should kept the entire screen black rather than irritating the viewers to find out what is actually happening on screen.

Slowly builds up, with just the right atmosphere, towards an unsettling finale. Successful characterization, giving the feel of the age the story is in. Makes you immersed in the story. This is in the same avenue as Hereditary and Midsommar. May not be some people's cup of tea, which is totally understandable. A good work, worth a watch.

This is by far one of the worst movies I've ever seen. I don't even want to glorify this thing by calling it a movie because it isn't. Movies have a plot and a storyline but this video doesn't have anything. Basically you are watching a family of religious lunatics that pray and cry for an hour and then they start disappearing one by one with no explanation, blaming each other for being witches or whatever and the movie offers no answers. What's even the point of filming something like this? I am sure all the pretentious people in the world will call this "high art" and glorify it right and left but it doesn't make this a good movie. How can anyone with a brain seriously say this movie is anything but absolutely terrible? There is no plot, no storyline, no character development, no lessons to be learned, nothing. Everything about this movie is absolute garbage.

Review_Title: Not perfect, but dark and twisted.
Review_Text: For anyone saying this acting is "horrible", that simply isn't true. For anyone saying the script is bad, read more books. For anyone saying the plot doesn't make any sense, read The Crucible. The acting was phenomenal, the story was dark, the suspense was high. Anyone rating this movie a 1 quite literally doesn't understand the basics of a movie. Watch this movie, form your own opinion.
A Witch's Tale Like No Other: A Film Review"

The Witch is a masterpiece. It will not be everyone's cup of tea, but it is perfectly executed psychological religious horror. After reading so many mixed reviews, I had zero expectations.. the perfect viewer recipe. What a visceral experience... Don't let the opening scenes scare you off, it only gets better. I suggest turning on subtitles, the dialog/accents are difficult to understand. It would have been disappointing watching this in theaters due to a lack of subtitles. The only critique I can offer is that I wish the film was extended, especially the beginning, to provide more "origin" and context. Like where was the settlement, who built it, where did the animals come from? If the film had a longer runtime it would have helped develop the situation a bit better. The intro happens so fast (along with the horror), that it took me out of the movie for a second, but it was very effective in slowly pulling me back in. In a sense, that might have been intentional. Wild ride. If you appreciated this movie, you might also like Silence (2016).
This might be my least favorite movie of all time. The only thing slower than this movie is my 90 year old grandma driving on the freeway.

Stunning acting. Constant mood of threat. Period detail spot on. People going on and on about it not having enough horror are way off bat. This is about religious fanaticism. Blind faith. The only annoying part was the mumbled dialogue throughout making it impossible to understand. Thought provoking. Disturbing.
Slow and uneventful
One of the best horror films to be produced in the last decade. Great performances, time period perfection. Paranoia and devilry at its finest.

Great script, beautifully filmed with amazing child actors! I grew up on The Crucible and related content so I had expectations and I'm not disappointed! Harvey Scrimshaw as Caleb turns in the *MOST* incredible performance and his mastery of Olde English is positively riveting, I look forward to seeing more of him in the future! The subtle inclusion of lore and imagery helps to move the story forward without giving away too much. But brace yourself for the pecking crow, you'll cringe regardless of how steely you believe yourself to be. Also, Black Phillip isn't a sweater wearing yoga goat so it's okay if you don't want to cuddle him.

This is a first rate movie for those who believe in God, Satan, witches, evil forces, a spirit world, levitation, transmutation, etc. For others, it's admirable for its re-creation of sets, costumes, lighting, language and community in 17th century New England. Director Robert Eggers makes an auspicious debut and gets solid performances from an inexperienced cast including children and animals. The dialect is difficult, especially when so many lines are mumbled or whispered, so audiences abroad, who get subtitles may follow it better. When I lived in Maine, sociologists told me that pedophilia and incest were more common there than elsewhere, due to social isolation and distances from communities. Hence, the bizarre behavior of uneducated people, living virtually in a forest, among farm and feral animals. This nearly believable horror story engages for its brisk 92 minutes.

The Witch is... Interesting. The acting is ok, honestly I kept getting distracted by the script. The emotions were there but the dialogue just felt awkward and forced to me. It's also slowly paced, making the whole thing feel long and drawn out. Still, there are themes in here that I found relevant and poignant. The notion that with a single word, a simple label someone can be destroyed without needing the burden of proof. Still, themes aside, the movie is dull even though it tries very hard not to be. Perhaps that's the problem, it's trying too hard.

WHAT A DEBUT FOR EGGERS!!!! This is a amazing and unusual horror movie. The movie doesn't have any jump scares, it isn't a horror movie for mainstream audiences. The performances are great, the directing and the cinematography are brilliant. It is a one of the best and one of the most beautiful movies of 2015. The writing is intelligent and the story is very interesting and captivating. I love the dialog and how Robert Eggers puts so much effort to be as similar as possible with the time period. I personally prefer The Lighthouse over this one but both are great I am sure Eggers will be a legend of cinema. Also the story is full of metaphors and similarities to the bible and Christianity
Should be a straight to dvd made for tv movie

This movie is an amazing gothic, dark, atmospheric and artistic horror movie. I really enjoyed the plot that was taking place in the dark medieval times. The characters were very interesting and well-written. The acting was very good also. The best elements of the movie in my opinion were the cinematography, score and the atmosphere of the movie. The atmosphere of the film was very dark and I really liked that for a low budget film it kinda scared me especially as the film comes to an end it becomes more creepy, surreal and weird. To sum up I really enjoyed "The VVitch" and I think it's for sure one of the best horror movies of 21st century. Robert Eggers did a great job for his first movie and I think this movie is worth watching especially for folk horror or witch horror fans.
The Finale is the Best

Loved the creepy atmosphere and the period in which this movie takes place. Definitely worth watching, though if you're looking for a scare-your-pants off slaughter-fest, this is probably not for you. A little different from others though, so worth watching just for that.

For all the Rich Atmosphere, Gothic horror and so on that seems to make people go crazy, this movie never gets scary. Not even once. It just drags on without ever getting to anything scary, one kids gets "possessed" and I just laughed it was so comically bad.

Review_Title: I enjoyed all of these 90 minutes.
Review_Text: 'The Witch', Robert Eggers' feature directorial debut, is very good! I enjoyed all of these 90 minutes, I could've watched it go on for a little longer in truth. I really liked the atmosphere throughout, as well as the look of the film. The dialogue is particularly excellent, too. Everyone on the cast gives a terrific performance, shown perfectly by that final scene with them all together onscreen. Harvey Scrimshaw is super convincing in the aforementioned, I was almost questioning if they had got an adult actor and morphed him into Caleb, such was his high performance. Ellie Grainger and Lucas Dawson are class in that scene too, one of the most unsettling moments in this is as their characters convulse on the floor - that sorta thing with kids always creeps me out. I've gone too far into my review to not note Anya Taylor-Joy, who is quality from beginning to end. Ralph Ineson and Kate Dickie merit props as well. I mentioned in my recent review of (the good) 'Nosferatu' that I was unsure how this one was going to fare in my personal ranking of this director's work, given the stark contrast with my thoughts on 'The Lighthouse' (4/10) and 'The Northman' (9/10). In actuality, this falls a notch below the latter; not far off the same rating, fwiw. It'll be fascinating to see what Eggers conjures up next, as long as it is not another piece in the ilk of that from 2019 then I'll excited to check it out.

Review_Title: Can't reach the pedestal the fans put it on.
Review_Text: I waited too long time to watch this. After so many touting how good it was I finally gave it a shot. It suffers from the equivalent of the Family Guy hurt knee joke that goes way too long only the uncomfortable length isn't a punchline. Far too many scenes just drag like it's trying to pad out the run time. Some will call it "being impatient" or some other "you just don't understand art" cast-aside argument. I love movies that take time to breathe and take their time but holy cow this rubbed my patience raw. Far too many movies have lengthy LENGTHY staring then cuts to looking at nothing.....just learn how to trim movie bloat. Another problem is that I found the sound design to be unfinished. There's way too many moments when I wondering if I accidentally muted the tv. Doesn't need dialog, doesn't need a constant swelling score. There's long moments when I should hear breathing or footsteps or some audio sensory. A good note is that the story is simple and interesting but more for a top notch 30-40 minute anthology story.

Knowing that this is an A24 horror film, it usually has more creepy vibe rather than scary which I also like. The movie really portraits the said era. After the best Hereditary film, this comes after. Anya Taylor-Joy really is the best at horror films from her young age. She starts the film with being innocent and naive until she became omnipotent and that's a good character development since she is "The Witch". I knew the Queen's Gambit girl is the best at horror films. The movie is totally creepy and will leave you having goosebumps until the end. It totally depicts a girl going through maturity and comprehends that she'll eventually experience such chaos in her family. A really good movie to originate a folktale. The only criticism I personally have is how they talk, I sometimes cannot understand their conversation or is it just my perception that is low and besides it's from New England. Overall, there are certain parts that needs to augmentate but it's a 2015 film so, it may be the best!!!

Calling The Witch a horror movie is somewhat misleading. Fan of thrillers? - It's a good movie. Fan of Dark Mysteries? - It's a good movie. Fan or horror? It's a good movie. Fan of Historical movies? Hell it might even make you happy too. This movie takes the story of fear, paranoia, and the fear of God not to the extreme, but to what people at the time truly believed. The slow burning tension is masterfully created not only by the combination of the acting, the cinematography, and the writing. Even the subtle score is well put together and not over the time, not brewing up to cheap jump scares or slashing moments. I myself am a fan of horror, however most horror movies often leave me feeling unfulfilled and unsatisfied. For those who feel this way on an even more dissatisfied level, this movie may be the one that brings the genre of Horror to a level playing field for your interests. Watch The Witch, but with expectations of it being a movie. Not a horror movie or a thriller or whatever genre bending semantic you may want to use, just go into it with an open mind and expect what you would watching anything that wasn't a horror film. Watch the characters become introduced to a new world as the mystery unfolds of a fear birthed lore.

Talk about old school! "The Witch" is a painstaking recreation of Puritan life in New England. The lifestyle is mimicked. The clothes are period-accurate. The dialogue is actually based off of documents and speeches from that time. It's as if Mel Gibson decided to update "The Passion of the Christ" by 1700 years. As mentioned, the movie is set in Puritan New England as a family is banished from the larger community and has to make their own way out in the wilderness. As they build their home, strange things begin to happen, starting with the abduction of the infant Samuel. Things continue to get worse and worse, until... okay, no spoilers. See the movie. This is a dark and effective movie. I can't remember the last time I actually had a start from the all too often used jump scares, but the movie is absorbing enough that it did manage to "get" me a couple times. Robert Eggers seems to have kicked off a new wave in old-school, deep supernatural and existential horror. I won't lie that I drew some comparisons between this and Ari Aster's "Hereditary," if nothing else than by simply the way the movie felt and left me feeling at the end. That being said, the film isn't perfect. In fact, oddly enough, it's perfection is what gives it imperfection. The period is so painstakingly recreated, in particular the dialogue, that sometimes hearing it can be jarring, making me stop for just a second to think about what was just said, which unfortunately interrupts the flow and managed to pull me out of the film. It's kind of a strange complaint that something could be so accurate that it fails to suspend disbelief, but here we are. "The Witch" is quite an achievement and I'm glad that this film, which would otherwise be relegated to underground status, has managed to achieve a following, enough so that Robert Eggers got to do a follow-up with the Lovecraftian-looking "The Lighthouse." Definitely worth checking out.
The only thing scary about this movie was how boring it was

Honestly, this is horror done right. Coming from two decades of generic slashers and wannabe tension driven psychological dramas (which didn't work out), The VVitch is a huge step in the right direction and gave start to the last 9 years of a genre's revival. Eggers cast perfectly, the location and setting are astonishingly eerie and the isolation felt is so real. The twins make me want to reconsider my stance on not hitting children, Taylor-Joy's performance is subtle but great, Dickie is very similar to her character in Game of Thrones, but it works. The boy is second best imo but the absolute show stealer for me is Ralph Ineson. 10/10 Haunting sound design, specific colour grading and authentic dialogue give this movie a unique style which is hard to find in this genre. Some clunky editing in the middle and tad bit over the top -ness reduce it to an 8 out of 10 for me. But it's still great! The last 25 minutes are certainly a highlight and make me recommend it to all horror fans.

I think I was cursed. I had to have been because that was one painful experience. I must've been bewitched into even watching this drivel. I don't know what I liked less: the constant yelling, the old English or the backwardness of the family. Just to bring you up to speed real quick: It's 17th century America and a family has just been banished from a colony due to their particular practice of the Gospel. Not long after settling in their new digs the baby is stolen away by what is presumably a witch. From that point on a lot of yelling, praying and insanity ensues. I couldn't understand them much of the time due to the accents, the speech and the volume. And remember, it's the 17th century which means no electricity--so be prepared for darkness to ruin some scenes. I know that the Salem Witch Trials were real but this movie just made a mockery of it all. The more the family doubled down on prayer the more psychotic they became. I don't know if this movie was about the frailty of faith and prayer or the power of witchcraft. Give me the good ol' green witch on a broomstick.
Description of the witch movie

I am not really a horror movie fan. I can tolerate Stephen King at times, and I can enjoy an old Lon Chaney or Vincent Price flick. But, to my mind, horror is not the same as suspense. A finely crafted scene implying gore is much more artistic and compelling than a blood-filled chainsaw scene. The Witch is not a horror film, and yet the events are horrible. It is a really good film worth watching. And maybe a second watching.

Yeah, this is one of the good ones. A family of outcasts are besieged by evil, an evil that attempts to shatter the family unit by creating an atmosphere of paranoia amongst them, turning them against one another. Against one character in particular. All to isolate and infect said character with hopelessness. Leaving the innocent character with nothing but a string of betrayals by everyone she ever loved-this is how you make a witch. The authenticity of the dialogue is unbelievable. The locations really feel like the untainted America, pre 1700's. You are in the middle of nowhere, outcast, under attack and with no one to help you. I felt like I was peering into the past, witnessing something horrible that really happened, but was lost to history. The imagery and symbolism are mind blowing. I don't buy many films, but I did this one.

Well it's not the first time I got conned by the ratings a movie gets on IMDb, and it's probably not going to be the last time either. I find it just incredible that this movie gets such a high rating compared to other jewels that are scored poorly. If you are a horror movie fan like me, and by that I mean real horror, the kind that gives you the creeps, then I advise you to pass on this one. Because honestly there is absolutely nothing horror-like about The Witch. To resume the movie in short it is very simple, people speak the old English in a way that you want to punch them in the face after fifteen minutes, there is about 0% suspense or anything worth mentioning, it's a complete waste of your time. But if you like that kind of crap movies, with on top of that half of the movie religion bullshit, with no action at all, then you might like The Witch. The actors are so-so, it's obvious those ones will never win any prizes with their acting skills, let that be said. Anyways, shame on me that I have been fooled by the ratings again. Don't make the same mistake I did.

Review_Title: Well executed Horror film all around.
Review_Text: Felt compelled to watch this after seeing one of Egger's other films, 'The Lighthouse'. His work proves to be exceptional, even after following into this grim subject of witchcraft. Can't say I've seen a worthwhile 'witch' movie since "the Craft" but this one definitely lives up to that unknown world of dark magic. Everything from the Christian slurs, to the naked chants in the forest, and hateful curses coming from the mouths of children. Although I am not someone of this practice, the portrayal of the craft felt well executed throughout the film. At least in terms of what I've always imagined these types of things to be like, which in layman's terms is a deep rooted spiritual warfare for the believers of God and non-believers of God. The destruction of the nuclear family, the infamous black goat, the mysterious loom of the bonfire, and the remote forestry all combined for the perfect magical horror recipe. Needless to say, the acting performances from pretty much the entire cast was superb. The character's were all given enough spotlight where it didn't leave any open ended questions. Great film all in all, thoroughly entertaining even for the weary old soul.

Review_Title: If you're looking for horror, you won't find it here
Review_Text: This movie was so bad that I had to sign up for an account with IMDb, to let my rant be heard worldwide! I was really looking forward to this film from the first trailer last year! The best thing I can say about this movie is that it's only 90 minutes long. 90 minutes of trying to understand what the people are saying,and hoping to catch at least a glimpse of "the witch". The acting in the movie is actually pretty good. It's just the movie itself that sucked. I have no idea where these fabulous reviews are coming from. People actually rejoiced when the movie ended. I felt a serge of energy sweep over my body, and felt the need to go out into the world and make a difference (to make up for the lost 90 minutes of my life). You can go the rest of your life without seeing this film. It is that bad.

A horror film truly worthy of its name, with excellent tension and a disturbing (to say the least) psychological game. Horror cinema is overloaded with average or bad productions, and that's why I believe we have every reason to congratulate a work that manages to stand out and stand out from the crowd for the best reasons. I'm not going to make the mistake that many professional critics have made and indulge in grandiloquent praise that calls this film the horror masterpiece of the decade, or one of the scariest films of their lifetimes. I won't do that because that would be a huge exaggeration and unfair to several other quality horror films. But yes, this is a very, very well made film, and worth every penny of the movie ticket. I will definitely recommend it to friends. The action takes place in 17th century New England, among the English communities of radical Protestant religion, the so-called Puritans. The film invites us to follow a Puritan family who are excluded from their community due to religious differences, and who are forced to live on the edge of civilization, on a small isolated farm on the edge of the forest. For whatever reason, they did not feel any fear of the native Amerindians who inhabited those regions, nor did they think about them when terrible things began to happen to them and the family's baby was kidnapped. To the ultra-religious and fearful minds of these people, it could not be more evident that there is a diabolical witch, a servant of Satan, disturbing their peaceful and most Christian existence. And of course, to the audience's delight, they couldn't have been more right! Since they don't know who she is, suspicions start right inside the house and a kind of "cabin fever" develops. How will it all end? You better see! Let's start with the not so good part, which for me comes down to the written script. The story is good and is set in an attractive historical period where religious hysteria and witch hunts were real. That is, if we traveled back in time and could go to that region we would find people with similar attitudes and thoughts. This is very good and writer/director Robert Eggers shows that he did his homework and read some books about the time and the mindset of those people. But, as the people say, the Devil is in the details: even though they were ostracized, did they have to move so far away from the settlement that they would expose themselves to danger? Why are there almost no other characters? Anyway, I can handle these little script details just fine. On a technical level, the film is very solid and presents us with very well-done cinematography, an excellent filming job that makes the most of the candlelight, the yellowish tone they give off, and the shadows they leave in the environment. The soundtrack and sound effects do a lot for the dark and tense atmosphere that the film begins to build from the beginning. There is not a moment where I felt that these elements were intrusive or omitted. The suspense and dramatic tension are magnificently modeled throughout the action, so much so that we don't even feel time passing: we are caught up in what we are seeing, and we want to see how it will end. The cast contributes enormously to the quality of the film, giving us superb dramatic performances, full of tension and authenticity. We cannot fail to say that Anya Taylor-Joy, who quickly establishes herself as an unequivocal protagonist, deserves all the applause she has received for this work, which consolidates the ascending career she has had over the last few years. Ralph Ineson is also not far behind and is probably the one who receives the most complex and difficult character to play. Kate Dickie, meanwhile, takes her character on a gradual descent into hysterical madness as she watches her life fall apart piece by piece. Harvey Scrimshaw and Ellie Grainger are very helpful with the work they do and cannot be overlooked because of their age.

Review_Title: This is how one becomes a witch
Review_Text: I love the story. What I find so special about it is that it makes me believe that this is how one might really become a witch. Rejected by everyone. Under the pressure by some events one does not understand. Searching for some identity to cling on. Great performances by actors. Father loves his family and tries doing his best, but he 's kind of making an action first and thinking later. Mother is really like she's devoted her life to something what she's does not really want. And this is the film I fell in love with Anya Taylor-Joy. Overall it's one of my favorite movies - great forest visuals, story, performances and folktale-ish horror.
Beleaguered innocent farm girl turns witch in this 17th Century film

Review_Title: Not a "horror" movie - just a "horrible" movie.
Review_Text: Like many others, I was swayed...and fooled...by the overwhelmingly- positive reviews here and elsewhere. I'm still baffled as to what anyone found scary, frightening, horrible, unnerving, disturbing, etc about this film. Almost nothing happened in this movie. It was mostly an indecipherable look at a Puritan family alone on the 1600s American frontier and how guilty their version of Christianity made them at every turn. This film badly needed subtitles. I get that they're trying to be authentic but when 75% of the dialect is not understandable...well, that just makes the movie that less watchable. This movie needed the actual "VVitch" to appear more often. That might have made it more interesting. Instead, it was just scene after scene of the family's mother and father beating themselves up due to their warped fundamentalist Christianity. Black Phillip the Goat gets the lone star of my review, mostly for what he does near the end, which sped up my exit from this complete snoozefest of a movie. Same your time & spend your money on a different film. This one is horrible.

When a director has the courage of his (or her convictions), and doesn't resort to clichés and cheap scares to create a movie; coupled with a meticulous attention to detail, you end up with a movie like The Witch. There is a brooding tension right from the outset, and you really feel the plight and misery of the family's circumstances as their situation trying to struggle in a harsh and hostile environment reaches its conclusion. For fans of more old school horror film techniques, that rely on a story to develop through excellent acting and the use of 'what you don't see' rather than what you do, this film is for you. Think 'Whistle and I'll come to You' or 'The Haunting' for the 21st Century. I'm still not entirely sure I really enjoyed the ending. I can imagine Eggers might have had a few different options. I'm not saying it spoiled the film, it just felt like it jarred with the style of the previous 90 minutes, but I'm being picky! This is a mature and beautifully made film. An outstanding debut for the director.

Where's the horror? This movie had all of elements you would want in a great horror movie, except there was no horror. The music was chilling. The cinematography was strong in most cases, though it was hard to distinguish exactly what you were looking at. The dialogue could use subtitles, as these accents, whether fake or real, are uttered in such a glib manner that you'll have a tough time understanding. Oh, and the prayers. Someone is saying a prayer every five minutes in this movie. I thought I was at a Jimmy Swaggart prayer-a-thon. But that's not the biggest problem. This movie sets you up with suspense, chilling music, and some interesting imagery, AND DOES ABSOLUTELY NOTHING WITH IT. Think of this as M. Night's worst movie except with no attempt to scare you. Watch it on NetFlix....not even the tiniest bit scary.

In 2014, we have The Babadook. In 2015, we have It Follows. In 2016, we have THE WITCH // instagram: moviesmaniax In 2014, we have The Babadook. In 2015, we have It Follows. And so far in 2016, we have ourselves another horror masterpiece, The Witch. First time writer-director, Roger Eggers, has delivered a movie that is soul-shaking, intensely disturbing, and gleefully Satanic enough that will likely satisfy most horror fans who can tolerate slow-burn style of movie. The Witch slowly builds its tension and thanks to its terrific production, performance, and music, all of which fit perfectly to create a dreadful tone and pressuring the audience the whole way through. Like It Follows, the music in The Witch is just haunting and uneasy to listen to and really plays a huge part in creating the eerie atmosphere and tension effectively. The visual here is just as stunning and compelling as well with a brilliant production and setting that makes us feel like we are watching something we are not supposed to. While the story-line is not as spectacular as other elements in the film but it still manages to delivery the theme of faith and human nature effectively enough through the talented performance from all the cast. Even though this is a slow-burn horror film but it never gets boring as there are always something interesting and captivating to look at and the pacing here is just nicely flow with its tension rising up and down throughout the whole film. The Witch doesn't rely on any cheap scares, like most modern horror film did, or over-the-top gore to shock the audience but rather its theme and concept that really creeps the hell out of them and delivers a spine-chilling experience. The Witch succeeds in almost every aspect in filmmaking giving horror fans an eerily rich and devilish experience that's pleasantly disturbing throughout. It's excited to see what the writer-director, Robert Eggers, has to offer in the near future as he has proved with The Witch that there's still hope for a horror filmmaking once again. >>A-<<
